items.title: I can define the term stakeholder in a business context
items.what: A stakeholder is any individual or group that can either affect or be affected by the operations of a business. Stakeholders exist at all levels of the business environment.
items.why: Being able to clearly define this term is essential for all further analysis of stakeholder interests, conflicts, and responsibilities.
items.example: Employees are stakeholders because their livelihoods depend on the business, and their performance directly affects business success.

subtopic.name: Identifying Stakeholders
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers who the stakeholders of a business are and how they relate to the three levels of the business environment: macro, operating, and internal. A stakeholder is anyone who can either affect or be affected by the operations of a business.
subtopic.why: Understanding who the stakeholders are is the foundation for managing business relationships effectively. Without knowing who has a stake in the business, managers cannot anticipate pressures, resolve conflicts, or build strategies for success.

items.title: I can identify internal environment stakeholders of a business
items.what: Internal stakeholders are those within the business over which it has control. These include owners (or shareholders), directors, managers, and employees.
items.why: Internal stakeholders are closest to the daily operations and decision-making of the business, making them critical to its functioning and culture.
items.example: In a company like Coles, internal stakeholders include the board of directors who set strategy, store managers who run individual locations, and the thousands of employees who serve customers daily.

subtopic.name: Identifying Stakeholders
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers who the stakeholders of a business are and how they relate to the three levels of the business environment: macro, operating, and internal. A stakeholder is anyone who can either affect or be affected by the operations of a business.
subtopic.why: Understanding who the stakeholders are is the foundation for managing business relationships effectively. Without knowing who has a stake in the business, managers cannot anticipate pressures, resolve conflicts, or build strategies for success.

items.title: I can identify operating environment stakeholders of a business
items.what: Operating environment stakeholders are immediately external to the business and interact closely with it. These include customers, suppliers, and competitors.
items.why: These stakeholders have a direct, regular impact on business operations, influencing revenue, costs, and competitive positioning.
items.example: For Woolworths, a key supplier of fresh produce is an operating environment stakeholder because their pricing, quality, and delivery reliability directly affect what Woolworths can offer customers.

subtopic.name: Identifying Stakeholders
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers who the stakeholders of a business are and how they relate to the three levels of the business environment: macro, operating, and internal. A stakeholder is anyone who can either affect or be affected by the operations of a business.
subtopic.why: Understanding who the stakeholders are is the foundation for managing business relationships effectively. Without knowing who has a stake in the business, managers cannot anticipate pressures, resolve conflicts, or build strategies for success.

items.title: I can identify macro environment stakeholders of a business
items.what: Macro environment stakeholders include the general community and society. These operate in the broad environment over which the business has no direct control.
items.why: Even though a business cannot control macro stakeholders, their expectations around ethics, employment, and environmental responsibility shape how the business must operate.
items.example: The local community near a factory is a macro stakeholder because they are affected by potential pollution, noise, and traffic from the business, even though they have no direct business relationship with it.

subtopic.name: Identifying Stakeholders
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers who the stakeholders of a business are and how they relate to the three levels of the business environment: macro, operating, and internal. A stakeholder is anyone who can either affect or be affected by the operations of a business.
subtopic.why: Understanding who the stakeholders are is the foundation for managing business relationships effectively. Without knowing who has a stake in the business, managers cannot anticipate pressures, resolve conflicts, or build strategies for success.

items.title: I can distinguish between the three levels of the business environment when classifying stakeholders
items.what: The three levels are the internal environment (within the business), the operating environment (immediately external with close interaction), and the macro environment (broad conditions beyond the business's control).
items.why: Classifying stakeholders by environment level helps managers understand the degree of control they have over each relationship and tailor their strategies accordingly.
items.example: A manager at a real estate agency would classify their sales agents as internal environment stakeholders, their property-listing clients as operating environment stakeholders, and the broader suburban community as macro environment stakeholders.

subtopic.name: Identifying Stakeholders
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers who the stakeholders of a business are and how they relate to the three levels of the business environment: macro, operating, and internal. A stakeholder is anyone who can either affect or be affected by the operations of a business.
subtopic.why: Understanding who the stakeholders are is the foundation for managing business relationships effectively. Without knowing who has a stake in the business, managers cannot anticipate pressures, resolve conflicts, or build strategies for success.

items.title: I can describe the interests of owners and shareholders
items.what: Owners aim for profitability, ethical operations, and socially responsible behaviour. Shareholders specifically want to receive dividends (dividend yield) and see their share value increase (capital appreciation).
items.why: Owners and shareholders provide the financial foundation of a business, and understanding their interests is key to maintaining investment and business viability.
items.example: Shareholders in a publicly listed company like Coles expect to receive annual dividends from profits and want the share price to grow over time, giving them a return on their investment.

subtopic.name: Stakeholder Interests
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the specific interests and issues that each type of stakeholder has in relation to a business. Different stakeholders have different priorities, ranging from profitability and dividends to job satisfaction and environmental sustainability.
subtopic.why: Understanding what each stakeholder group wants from a business allows managers to make informed decisions that balance competing demands. Ignoring stakeholder interests can lead to conflict, reduced performance, and reputational damage.

items.title: I can describe the interests of managers and employees
items.what: Managers seek involvement in goal setting, fair remuneration, career development, and job satisfaction. Employees want fair wages, a non-discriminatory workplace, career advancement, job security, and to work for an ethical business.
items.why: These internal stakeholders drive the day-to-day operations of the business. Their satisfaction and motivation directly affect productivity, quality of service, and staff turnover.
items.example: An employee at Bunnings has an interest in receiving a fair wage, feeling secure in their long-term employment, and working in a respectful, diverse environment that values their contribution.

subtopic.name: Stakeholder Interests
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the specific interests and issues that each type of stakeholder has in relation to a business. Different stakeholders have different priorities, ranging from profitability and dividends to job satisfaction and environmental sustainability.
subtopic.why: Understanding what each stakeholder group wants from a business allows managers to make informed decisions that balance competing demands. Ignoring stakeholder interests can lead to conflict, reduced performance, and reputational damage.

items.title: I can describe the interests of customers
items.what: Customers want quality goods and services, high levels of customer service (both pre-sale and post-sale), and assurance that the business acts ethically and responsibly. Some customers also value supporting Australian-made or Australian-owned businesses.
items.why: Customers are the primary source of revenue for a business. Meeting their interests builds loyalty, repeat business, and a positive reputation.
items.example: A customer purchasing from Signet (a packaging supplier) is interested in receiving environmentally friendly, sustainably sourced packaging products that are delivered reliably and at a fair price.

subtopic.name: Stakeholder Interests
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the specific interests and issues that each type of stakeholder has in relation to a business. Different stakeholders have different priorities, ranging from profitability and dividends to job satisfaction and environmental sustainability.
subtopic.why: Understanding what each stakeholder group wants from a business allows managers to make informed decisions that balance competing demands. Ignoring stakeholder interests can lead to conflict, reduced performance, and reputational damage.

items.title: I can describe the interests of suppliers and competitors
items.what: Suppliers want their customers to be profitable so they get paid, want prompt payment, and seek long-term preferred supplier relationships. Competitors aim to gain competitive edge, greater market share, and to differentiate their products or services.
items.why: Suppliers and competitors are key operating environment stakeholders. Their actions influence costs, product availability, and market dynamics.
items.example: A produce supplier to Woolworths wants guaranteed ongoing orders, fair pricing, and prompt payment within agreed terms, while a competitor like Coles wants to attract more customers away from Woolworths through better pricing or service.

subtopic.name: Stakeholder Interests

subtopic.why: Understanding what each stakeholder group wants from a business allows managers to make informed decisions that balance competing demands. Ignoring stakeholder interests can lead to conflict, reduced performance, and reputational damage.

items.title: I can describe the interests of the community and society
items.what: The community benefits from employment opportunities and wants businesses to participate in their local area, act as responsible corporate citizens, operate ethically, and be environmentally sustainable.
items.why: Community expectations shape a business's social licence to operate. Businesses that ignore community interests risk public backlash, regulatory action, and loss of customer trust.
items.example: A community near a manufacturing plant expects the business to minimise pollution, create local jobs, and contribute to community events or causes, such as sponsoring a local sports club.

subtopic.name: Stakeholder Interests
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the specific interests and issues that each type of stakeholder has in relation to a business. Different stakeholders have different priorities, ranging from profitability and dividends to job satisfaction and environmental sustainability.
subtopic.why: Understanding what each stakeholder group wants from a business allows managers to make informed decisions that balance competing demands. Ignoring stakeholder interests can lead to conflict, reduced performance, and reputational damage.

items.title: I can identify potential conflicts between owners/directors and shareholders
items.what: Shareholders want to receive substantial dividends from profits, while owners and directors may prefer to retain a larger portion of profit to reinvest in building the business.
items.why: This is one of the most common stakeholder conflicts. How profit is distributed versus reinvested affects both short-term returns and long-term business growth.
items.example: At the end of a profitable year, shareholders of a company may want 80% of profit distributed as dividends, but the directors want to retain 60% to fund a new warehouse, leading to disagreement at the annual general meeting.

subtopic.name: Stakeholder Conflicts
subtopic.what: This subtopic examines how the interests of different stakeholders can come into conflict with each other. Because stakeholders have different priorities, tensions naturally arise that businesses must manage.
subtopic.why: Recognising and understanding potential conflicts between stakeholders is essential for managers. Unresolved conflicts can harm business performance, damage relationships, and undermine long-term success.

items.title: I can identify potential conflicts between management and suppliers
items.what: Suppliers want fair prices, prompt payment, and a guaranteed ongoing relationship. Management wants consistent, high-quality goods delivered on time at the lowest possible cost.
items.why: This conflict highlights the tension between cost minimisation and maintaining strong supply chain relationships. Poor management of this conflict can lead to supply disruptions or reduced product quality.
items.example: A restaurant manager pushes a food supplier to lower their prices by 15%, but the supplier argues this would force them to use lower-grade ingredients, potentially reducing the quality of meals served to customers.

subtopic.name: Stakeholder Conflicts
subtopic.what: This subtopic examines how the interests of different stakeholders can come into conflict with each other. Because stakeholders have different priorities, tensions naturally arise that businesses must manage.
subtopic.why: Recognising and understanding potential conflicts between stakeholders is essential for managers. Unresolved conflicts can harm business performance, damage relationships, and undermine long-term success.

items.title: I can identify potential conflicts between business owners and the community
items.what: Business operations may cause environmental issues such as air or water pollution if owners fail to install or maintain proper equipment. The community wants to live in an environmentally safe area free from pollutants.
items.why: This conflict can result in legal action, fines, loss of community trust, and long-term reputational damage if not addressed proactively.
items.example: A factory owner avoids spending $200,000 on updated pollution filters to protect profits, but nearby residents complain about poor air quality and petition the local council to intervene.

subtopic.name: Stakeholder Conflicts
subtopic.what: This subtopic examines how the interests of different stakeholders can come into conflict with each other. Because stakeholders have different priorities, tensions naturally arise that businesses must manage.
subtopic.why: Recognising and understanding potential conflicts between stakeholders is essential for managers. Unresolved conflicts can harm business performance, damage relationships, and undermine long-term success.

items.title: I can identify potential conflicts between management and customers
items.what: Management may reduce the quality of goods or services to cut costs without lowering prices. Customers expect quality products at a fair price and do not want to be overcharged or under-serviced.
items.why: Failing to meet customer expectations erodes trust and loyalty, ultimately reducing sales and market share even if short-term costs are lowered.
items.example: A department store reduces staffing on the shop floor to save on wages, leading to longer wait times and poor customer service, causing customers to shop at competing stores instead.

subtopic.name: Stakeholder Conflicts
subtopic.what: This subtopic examines how the interests of different stakeholders can come into conflict with each other. Because stakeholders have different priorities, tensions naturally arise that businesses must manage.
subtopic.why: Recognising and understanding potential conflicts between stakeholders is essential for managers. Unresolved conflicts can harm business performance, damage relationships, and undermine long-term success.

items.title: I can discuss how stakeholder conflicts impact business decision-making
items.what: Businesses must develop strategies to balance or resolve conflicting stakeholder interests. Success comes from working out approaches that satisfy or overcome varying needs rather than ignoring them.
items.why: The ability to navigate stakeholder conflicts is a core management skill. Businesses that manage these tensions well are more likely to retain stakeholder support and achieve long-term success.
items.example: When Coles decided to stop selling single-use plastic tableware (benefiting the community and environment), it had to ensure customers were offered affordable alternatives made from FSC-certified materials, balancing environmental responsibility with customer satisfaction.

subtopic.name: Stakeholder Conflicts

subtopic.why: Recognising and understanding potential conflicts between stakeholders is essential for managers. Unresolved conflicts can harm business performance, damage relationships, and undermine long-term success.

items.title: I can identify and describe the four areas of corporate social responsibility
items.what: CSR is traditionally broken into four areas: environmental responsibility (reducing harm to the natural environment), philanthropic responsibility (contributing to community causes), ethical responsibility (operating with integrity and fairness), and economic responsibility (being financially viable and sustainable).
items.why: Understanding these four areas provides a framework for evaluating how well a business meets its broader obligations beyond simply making a profit.
items.example: Woolworths demonstrates environmental responsibility by redesigning packaging to use 75% less plastic, philanthropic responsibility through its Free Fruit for Kids program, ethical responsibility through sourcing FSC-certified products, and economic responsibility by maintaining profitability to sustain operations.

subtopic.name: Corporate Social Responsibility
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the four areas of corporate social responsibility (CSR) — environmental, philanthropic, ethical, and economic — and how businesses implement CSR strategies that affect both internal and external stakeholders.
subtopic.why: CSR is increasingly expected by stakeholders and the wider community. Businesses that act in a socially responsible manner can build a positive reputation, retain quality employees, increase customer loyalty, and differentiate themselves from competitors.

items.title: I can describe how CSR creates benefits for internal stakeholders
items.what: A socially responsible business creates benefits for employees by positively affecting their satisfaction, motivation, and loyalty. This aligns with human resource objectives such as reducing staff turnover and improving employee satisfaction.
items.why: Internal stakeholders who feel proud of their employer's social responsibility are more likely to stay, perform well, and contribute positively to the business culture.
items.example: Employees at Bunnings may feel greater pride and loyalty knowing the company actively pursues sustainability, values diversity, and engages with local communities, reducing the likelihood they will seek employment elsewhere.

subtopic.name: Corporate Social Responsibility
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the four areas of corporate social responsibility (CSR) — environmental, philanthropic, ethical, and economic — and how businesses implement CSR strategies that affect both internal and external stakeholders.
subtopic.why: CSR is increasingly expected by stakeholders and the wider community. Businesses that act in a socially responsible manner can build a positive reputation, retain quality employees, increase customer loyalty, and differentiate themselves from competitors.

items.title: I can describe how CSR creates benefits for external stakeholders
items.what: Communicating positive CSR activities to external stakeholders such as customers and the community helps increase consumer satisfaction, trust, and loyalty. It also provides a point of differentiation from competitors.
items.why: External stakeholders increasingly make purchasing and partnership decisions based on a business's social and environmental track record. CSR can be a genuine competitive advantage.
items.example: Coles' 'Together to Zero' sustainability strategy, including donating unsold food through SecondBite (providing 136 million meals over a decade), builds community trust and customer loyalty that competitors without similar programs may lack.

subtopic.name: Corporate Social Responsibility
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the four areas of corporate social responsibility (CSR) — environmental, philanthropic, ethical, and economic — and how businesses implement CSR strategies that affect both internal and external stakeholders.
subtopic.why: CSR is increasingly expected by stakeholders and the wider community. Businesses that act in a socially responsible manner can build a positive reputation, retain quality employees, increase customer loyalty, and differentiate themselves from competitors.

items.title: I can describe how legislation supports CSR in Australia
items.what: The Competition and Consumer Act 2010 (Commonwealth) establishes guidelines for businesses regarding disclosure of product information including performance, composition, contents, design, construction, and packaging. Many businesses go beyond legal compliance by becoming signatories to initiatives like the Australian Packaging Covenant.
items.why: Legislation sets the minimum standard for responsible business conduct. Understanding this helps explain why some CSR actions are legally required while others are voluntary commitments that further enhance a business's reputation.
items.example: The Australian Packaging Covenant's 2025 targets include 100% reusable, recyclable, or compostable packaging and 70% of plastic packaging being recycled or composted. Signet, a packaging company, voluntarily became a signatory to help its customers meet these targets.

subtopic.name: Corporate Social Responsibility

subtopic.why: CSR is increasingly expected by stakeholders and the wider community. Businesses that act in a socially responsible manner can build a positive reputation, retain quality employees, increase customer loyalty, and differentiate themselves from competitors.

items.title: I can apply CSR concepts to real business examples
items.what: Applying CSR knowledge means being able to analyse how specific businesses implement socially responsible strategies and evaluate the effects these have on their stakeholders and overall success.
items.why: The VCE exam requires students to apply their knowledge to case studies and contemporary examples, not just recall definitions. Practising application builds deeper understanding.
items.example: Woolworths removed plastic shopping bags entirely in 2022 (having replaced free single-use bags with 15-cent reusable bags in 2018). Analysing this involves identifying which stakeholders are affected (customers, community, suppliers of alternative bags) and evaluating whether the strategy strengthens Woolworths' reputation and long-term viability.

items.title: I can define corporate culture
items.what: Corporate culture is a system of shared values and beliefs of people within a business. It determines how people behave, act towards one another, and what is or is not accepted behaviour. It is often described as 'how we do things around here'.
items.why: This is a foundational definition that underpins all further discussion of culture in business management. A clear understanding is essential for exam responses.
items.example: At Moose Toys, the corporate culture — called 'The Moose Way' — includes values like kindness, teamwork, diversity of thinking, and personal responsibility, shaping how employees interact and make decisions every day.

subtopic.name: Corporate Culture
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the definition and elements of corporate culture, including both observable and non-observable elements. It also examines the important distinction between official (desired) culture and real (unofficial) culture.
subtopic.why: Corporate culture is an internal factor that directly affects business performance, employee engagement, and competitiveness. Understanding the gap between official and real culture is essential for diagnosing business problems and proposing solutions.

items.title: I can identify observable and non-observable elements of corporate culture
items.what: Observable elements (artefacts) include language, symbols, uniforms, office layout, logos, and visible behaviours. Non-observable elements include shared values that influence behaviour and deeper assumptions about human nature and the business environment.
items.why: Being able to distinguish between what can be seen and what lies beneath the surface helps in analysing whether a business's culture is genuine or superficial.
items.example: At a business where staff wear uniforms with the company logo (observable artefact), the non-observable element might be a shared belief that presenting a professional, unified image to customers builds trust and loyalty.

subtopic.name: Corporate Culture
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the definition and elements of corporate culture, including both observable and non-observable elements. It also examines the important distinction between official (desired) culture and real (unofficial) culture.
subtopic.why: Corporate culture is an internal factor that directly affects business performance, employee engagement, and competitiveness. Understanding the gap between official and real culture is essential for diagnosing business problems and proposing solutions.

items.title: I can describe official corporate culture
items.what: Official corporate culture is the desired culture that a business wishes to establish. It is the formal written expression of the business's values and beliefs, visible through company documents, goals, mission statements, slogans, and logos. It represents 'who we say we are and what we say we do'.
items.why: Official culture sets the standard and aspiration for the business. It communicates to stakeholders what the business stands for and provides a benchmark against which actual behaviour can be measured.
items.example: A real estate agency's official culture might include a vision statement that says 'Happy clients are our first priority', displayed in the office reception area and on all marketing materials.

subtopic.name: Corporate Culture
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the definition and elements of corporate culture, including both observable and non-observable elements. It also examines the important distinction between official (desired) culture and real (unofficial) culture.
subtopic.why: Corporate culture is an internal factor that directly affects business performance, employee engagement, and competitiveness. Understanding the gap between official and real culture is essential for diagnosing business problems and proposing solutions.

items.title: I can describe real (unofficial) corporate culture
items.what: Real corporate culture is what actually prevails in a business. It represents 'who we actually are and what we actually do'. It is observed through the real relationships, interactions, and behaviours between people in the workplace.
items.why: The real culture reveals whether the business is living up to its stated values. A significant gap between official and real culture can indicate serious management problems and lead to poor performance.
items.example: A real estate agency may have an official culture focused on client satisfaction, but if agents regularly arrive late, forget client appointments, and show little interest in attracting new listings, the real culture is one of low accountability and poor service.

subtopic.name: Corporate Culture
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the definition and elements of corporate culture, including both observable and non-observable elements. It also examines the important distinction between official (desired) culture and real (unofficial) culture.
subtopic.why: Corporate culture is an internal factor that directly affects business performance, employee engagement, and competitiveness. Understanding the gap between official and real culture is essential for diagnosing business problems and proposing solutions.

items.title: I can compare official and real corporate culture
items.what: Comparing the two involves identifying the gap between what a business says it values (official) and what actually occurs in practice (real). When the two align, the culture is strong and positive. When they differ significantly, it signals problems that management must address.
items.why: This comparison is a key analytical skill for the VCE exam. Being able to identify and discuss the gap between official and real culture demonstrates higher-order thinking.
items.example: Carrington Pty Ltd, a real estate agency, has an official culture stating 'Happy clients are our first priority', but a management consultant found that agents were uninterested in attracting clients and customer service was poor — showing a significant gap between official and real culture that was costing market share.

items.title: I can describe how mission, vision, and values statements shape corporate culture
items.what: The mission statement defines the purpose of the business. The vision statement sets out its aspirations. The values statement outlines what the business recognises as its core values, such as integrity, honesty, and responsibility. Together, these documents act as the starting point for establishing a desired culture.
items.why: These statements provide the foundation upon which all business decisions should align. Without them, employees lack a shared understanding of what the business stands for.
items.example: Bunnings' guiding principles — integrity, respect, teamwork, achievement, and innovation — are stated as the keys to its culture and achieving its vision, giving its 50,000+ team members a clear framework for expected behaviour.

subtopic.name: Developing Corporate Culture
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the strategies that businesses can use to develop and maintain a positive corporate culture, including mission and values statements, management structures, management styles, policies, people, physical environment, and stories and rituals.
subtopic.why: A positive corporate culture does not happen by accident. Managers must deliberately implement strategies to shape culture, and understanding these strategies is essential for proposing and justifying solutions in exam scenarios.

items.title: I can describe how management structures influence corporate culture
items.what: The structure of a business determines how work tasks are divided, who holds authority, and how communication flows. Traditional hierarchical structures have three levels (senior, middle, front-line management). Many businesses have moved to flatter structures through delayering, which increases employee involvement and reduces status distinctions.
items.why: Structure shapes daily interactions, decision-making, and communication. A flatter structure tends to promote a more collaborative, participative culture, while a tall hierarchy may reinforce a more formal, top-down culture.
items.example: A business that removes a layer of middle management (delayering) may find that employees feel more empowered to contribute ideas, communication improves, and the culture shifts from autocratic to participative.

subtopic.name: Developing Corporate Culture

subtopic.why: A positive corporate culture does not happen by accident. Managers must deliberately implement strategies to shape culture, and understanding these strategies is essential for proposing and justifying solutions in exam scenarios.

items.title: I can describe how management styles affect corporate culture
items.what: Management styles range from autocratic (task-focused, manager makes decisions alone) to participative (employee-centred, workers contribute to decision-making). A more employee-centred style demonstrates that the business values workers' contributions and builds trust.
items.why: The management style adopted by leaders directly shapes the day-to-day experience of employees. It influences motivation, job satisfaction, and whether the real culture matches the official culture.
items.example: At Insentra, CEO Ronnie Altit holds weekly '45 minutes with Ronnie' calls where employees can ask questions and chat, demonstrating a participative style that reinforces the company's culture of accessibility and transparency.

subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the strategies that businesses can use to develop and maintain a positive corporate culture, including mission and values statements, management structures, management styles, policies, people, physical environment, and stories and rituals.
subtopic.why: A positive corporate culture does not happen by accident. Managers must deliberately implement strategies to shape culture, and understanding these strategies is essential for proposing and justifying solutions in exam scenarios.

items.title: I can describe how policies reinforce corporate culture
items.what: A policy is a written statement detailing processes, procedures, rules, and regulations for a given situation. Policies establish consistency, set out procedures, recognise rights and obligations, identify how conflicts can be resolved, and ensure compliance with desired behaviours.
items.why: Policies translate cultural values into enforceable standards. Without clear policies, cultural expectations remain vague and inconsistently applied.
items.example: A business with a 'social media usage' policy that prohibits using Facebook, Instagram, or TikTok during working hours establishes a consistent standard — any employee who breaks the rule faces the same consequence, reinforcing a culture of professionalism.

items.title: I can describe how people and diversity contribute to corporate culture
items.what: The culture of a business is reflected in its people. Recruitment policies can create diversity in gender, ethnicity, age, skills, and experience. Having the right people who share or are willing to embrace the business's core values builds a coherent culture. Work-life balance practices also indicate whether the culture is genuinely positive.
items.why: Diversity enriches corporate culture by bringing different perspectives and ideas. A business that values its workers both professionally and personally creates stronger engagement and loyalty.
items.example: Bunnings is well known for employing people of varying ages, backgrounds, and ability levels, which contributes to a diverse, inclusive culture that reflects the communities it serves.

items.title: I can describe how the physical environment and material symbols indicate corporate culture
items.what: Physical environment includes office layout (e.g. open-plan vs. closed offices), business location, and design choices. Material symbols such as office size differences between managers, separate cafeterias, staff uniforms, and office colour schemes all communicate aspects of culture.
items.why: The physical environment provides immediate, visible cues about what a business values. Open-plan offices signal collaboration, while large executive offices and separate facilities signal hierarchy and status.
items.example: At Moose Toys, employees are encouraged to scribble ideas on whiteboard walls and there is a 'no lunch at your desk' rule, creating a physical environment that promotes creativity, collaboration, and social interaction.

items.title: I can describe how stories, narratives, and rituals reinforce corporate culture
items.what: Stories about significant events or founders create 'heroes' for the business. Rituals such as recognition ceremonies, weekly social gatherings, and annual celebrations underscore the importance of social interaction and the celebration of achievement.
items.why: Stories and rituals build emotional connection to the business and reinforce shared values over time. They help newcomers understand what the business stands for and what behaviour is celebrated.
items.example: Moose Toys holds bi-monthly talks followed by all-team lunches, art exhibition visits, and karaoke nights — rituals that strengthen relationships across departments and reinforce the company's fun, collaborative culture.
